name: Bare land
definition: Bare land and rock, including very sparse vegetation

name: Bare ground
definition: Areas of exposed, unvegetated land.

name: Bare rock
definition: Areas of exposed, unvegetated rock, such as scree, cliffs and limestone pavements. Only planimetric area is mapped, so large but near vertical cliffs may cover a small area when mapped, or even be missed.

name: Unconsolidated bare ground
definition: Ground types that are not fixed and can move around, such as loose sand, shingle or mud. Vegetation cover is sparse, as it is difficult for plants to root in unstable ground.

name: Sand
definition: Fine grains of rocks and minerals. Typically found coastally or by water systems.

name: Mud
definition: Clay/silt/fine sediments of earth and rocks mixed with water. Found near water.

name: Shingle
definition: Coarse fragments of rock, such as pebbles, rounded by the erosion of water. Typically found coastally or by water systems.

name: Walls
definition: A wall consisting of stones without mortar or cement.

name: Exposed peat
definition: Areas where Sphagnum mosses have disappeared and the bog has dried up, leaving bare peat as the dominant cover type.

name: Scree
definition: Loose rocks and broken rock fragments that accumulate near the base of mountains, cliffs hillsides following weathering and erosion.

name: Coastland
definition: Sand dunes/coastal grazing marsh/vegetated shingle

name: Sand dunes
definition: Sand along a shoreline that has been shaped into mounds and ridges by the wind. Maritime grasses stabilise these structure, e.g. Marram grass (Ammophila arenaria).

name: Coastal grazing marsh
definition: Pastures and meadows found near the coastline that are periodically covered by seawater.

name: Vegetated shingle
definition: Areas of shingle along the coastline that can support vegetation. This habitat is typically found above the mean high water spring tides and includes species such as: sea kale (Crambe maritima) and sea pea (Lathyrus japonicus).

name: Cropland
definition: Land used for growing crops

name: Annual crops
definition: Crops that complete their growing cycle within a year.

name: Permanent crops (vines, bushes, energy crops)
definition: Crops from plants that produce harvests year on year, and so are not grown in rotation, but occupy the same area/field year on year.

name: Orchards
definition: Collections of fruit and/or nut producing trees, currently managed for food production, with an intensely managed ground cover.

name: Grassland
definition: Permanent grasslands

name: Acid grassland
definition: Areas of acidic soils (pH <5.5) where primarily grasses and herbs grow. These soils are derived from sandstone and igneous rocks, or from deposits such as sands and gravels.

name: Lowland acid grassland
definition: Grassland that is found on acidic soils on top of sandstones and igneous rocks, typically below 300m in altitude.

name: Upland acid grassland
definition: Grassland that is found on acidic soils on top of sandstones and igneous rocks, typically above 300m in altitude.

name: Calcareous grassland
definition: Areas of basic soils where primarily grasses and herbs grow. These soils are derived from the weathering of base-rich rocks and types of limestone, including chalk.

name: Neutral grassland
definition: Areas of neutral soils (usually pH 4.5-6.5) where primarily grasses and herbs grow.

name: Modified grassland
definition: Areas of fertile, neutral soils where species-poor vegetation dominates. Modified grassland is often found on agricultural land that is intensively managed for grazing and/or fodder production.

name: Arable field margins
definition: Lines or sections of vegetation around arable fields, intended as beneficial for wildlife.

name: Heathland
definition: Land dominated by low (dwarf) shrub species, generally forming part of a succession from grassland to woodland but maintained through burning, cutting and grazing, e.g. moorlands. Includes grass moor as visually distinct from acid grassland and important as a transition between degraded (molinia dominated) landscapes and transition to blanket bog. Excludes seasonally and/or permanently wet areas, e.g. peat bogs.

name: Upland heath
definition: Typically found on acidic, low nutrient soils, these are areas consisting of >???% cover of Heather and heath species (Calluna vulgaris and Erica spp.) and/or Bilberry (Vaccinium myrtillus). Crowberry (Empetrum nigrum) may also be present. Management of upland heath can include regular patch burning, which can be easily identified aerially.

name: Upland dry heath
definition: Generally found in areas with low nutrient, acidic to circumneutral soils, which drain freely. Heather (Calluna vulgaris) and heath (Erica spp.) dominated, with other dwarf shrubs including Bilberry (Vaccinium spp.) and Crowberry (Empetrum nigrum).

name: Dwarf shrub dominated blanket bog
definition: Predominantly inactive bog areas. Dwarf shrub cover - including Heather and heath species (Calluna vulgaris and Erica spp.) – exceeds 75% of the canopy, and mosses (e.g. Sphagnum) are extremely rare if not completely absent.

name: Grass/sedge dominated blanket bog
definition: Areas which have the potential to become active blanket bogs. Sphagnum mosses typical of active bogs are scarce, and the area is dominated by grass and sedge. Common species include: purple moor grass (Molinia caerulea), cotton grass (Eriophorum angustifolium) and deer grass (Trichophorum cespitosum).

name: Dry grass/sedge dominated blanket bog
definition: Hydrological state captured as attribute

name: Wet grass/sedge dominated blanket bog
definition: Hydrological state captured as attribute

name: Bracken
definition: Areas are covered by at least ???% Bracken (Pteridium aquilinum). Variable in colour and appearance, it appears bright green and bushy in the summer, but russet-brown when the plant material has died.

name: Lowland heath
definition: Typically found on acidic, low nutrient soils, these areas are made up of varying percentages of Heather and heath species (Calluna vulgaris and Erica spp.), dwarf gorse (Vaccinium myrtillus) and Crowberry (Empetrum nigrum). Grass species such as Bristle Bent (Agrostis curtisii) and Sheep’s Fescue (Festuca ovina) are also common.

name: Scrubland
definition: Woody scrub species, associated with woodland or transitions to woodland in grassland or heathland habitats. Either having a diffuse boundary with a mix of woody shrubs and trees <5 m in height (with grasses) or in dense patches. These areas can be found within woodland or on the edges of woodland, maintained by grazing or as part of a natural succession to woodland. Includes patches of dense scrub with clear boundaries on heathland, e.g. gorse. Mature tree canopies should be digitised out. This class is separated from the (woodland/heathland/grassland) hierarchy as distinct landscape features.

name: Scrub
definition: Areas of shrubs <5m in height with >???% cover. Species may include Blackthorn (Prunus spinosa), Hawthorn (Crataegus spp.), Hazel (Corylus avellana), Bramble (Rubus fruticosus agg.) and Willow (Salix spp.), amongst others.

name: Mixed dense scrub
definition: Areas of scrub which contain multiple different species, with no one species dominating. Alternatively, areas of scrub dominated by a single species which isn’t Gorse (s1b).

name: Gorse
definition: Areas are covered by at least ???% Gorse. European Gorse (Ulex europaeus) dominates; Dwarf Gorse (Ulex minor) and Western Gorse (Ulex gallii) may also be present. Appears dark green, or is a distinct bright yellow when flowering.

name: Hedgerows
definition: Lines of shrubs <???m wide and <???m tall. Even though some species within the hedgerow may be capable of growing taller into trees, their shorter nature in this context results in the linear feature appearing as a ‘shrubby’ hedgerow. Often found at the boundaries of fields or bordering roads.

name: Unclassified
definition: NODATA

name: Artificial land
definition: Buildings, roads, built-up areas, artificially sealed surfaces, and quarries

name: Urban and transport
definition: Built-up land, such as buildings and car parks. Includes major and minor roads, as well as any human-made infrastructure.

name: Quarries, mineral workings and derelict land
definition: Includes both in use and decommissioned quarries and mineral workings, as well as derelict land – areas that previously had construction or developments on, but are now disused and abandoned.

name: Open mosaic
definition: Habitat found on previously disturbed or industrial land (brownfields) featuring a mix of bare ground, sparse vegetation (grasses, wildflowers, mosses), and sometimes pools, creating rich areas for rare invertebrates (insects) and reptiles

name: Water
definition: Rivers and lakes

name: Inland open water
definition: Natural and man-made bodies of water covering at least ???. Examples include lakes, pools, reservoirs and canals. Often appears very dark aerially.

name: Rivers and streams
definition: Rivers and streams from bank top to bank top (see UKHabs, specifications?). Often appears very dark aerially.

name: Wetland
definition: Seasonally and/or permanently wet areas

name: Freshwater fen, marsh and swamp
definition: Areas that are waterlogged, either permanently or periodically, and are often peat-forming. Fens receive groundwater, rainfall and water from surface run-off, separating them from bogs where the peat forming vegetation is isolated from groundwater. Marshes are dominated by herbaceous plants; swamps are dominated by trees and tall, emergent vegetation.

name: Upland mire
definition: Spring fed upland wetland (+ detail)

name: Saltmarsh
definition: Covers the area of land between where pioneer saltmarsh species start on mudflats, up to mature marsh. Nearest the shoreline vegetation which can survive frequent inundation is found, whereas at the transitional zone near the upper saltmarsh, only species which can survive occasional inundation are found.

name: Peat bog
definition: Areas where there is the permanent or frequent periodic presence of water, leading to waterlogged habitats with peat formation. Key indicator species include Sphagnum mosses.

name: Rushes
definition: Areas with species from the Juncaceae family.

name: Rushes in pasture
definition: Clumps of rushes, in patches or following drainage (blocked) or where water accumulates in fields

name: Upland rush pasture
definition: Clumps of vegetation dominated by rushes in poorly draining areas that form distinct features

name: Reedbed
definition: Swamp dominated by Common Reed

name: Woodland
definition: Trees & woodland canopies

name: Broadleaved woodland
definition: Areas dominated by trees >5m tall. There must be a tree canopy cover of at least ???%, with ≥???% consisting of deciduous, broadleaved species. Includes ancient and recent woodland, with trees that have grown from seed or planted seedlings. Tends to have shades of green and appear full in the summer, with a more brown and sparse appearance in the winter when the leaves have been lost.

name: Single trees (broadleaved)
definition: Isolated, broadleaved trees outside woodland. Only includes individual trees; as soon as there are more than one it must be classed as c1.

name: Hedgerow trees (broadleaved)
definition: Trees (broadleaved) within hedges, either single or lines.

name: Coniferous woodland
definition: Areas dominated by trees >5m tall. There must be a tree canopy cover of at least ???%, with ≥???% consisting of coniferous species. The majority of coniferous woodlands in the UK are from planted seedlings. Easily recognisable in aerial imagery, as plantations consist of uniformly aged, coloured and spaced trees, often with defined borders.

name: Single trees (coniferous)
definition: Isolated, coniferous trees outside woodland. Only includes individual trees; as soon as there are more than one it must be classed as c1.

name: Hedgerow trees (coniferous)
definition: Trees (coniferous) within hedges, either single or lines.

name: Traditional orchard
definition: Collections of fruit and/or nut producing trees, with low intensity management. The trees are found in more herbaceous ground cover than in an intensive orchard, and this category includes historical or abandoned orchards that still retain their trees.

name: Clear felled/newly planted
definition: Areas of woodland that have been recently felled or planted with new, young trees. Evidence of logging, rowing up of trash and drainage may be present. Newly planted trees can be identified by lines of uniform planting.
